description:
How can you not LOVE the Painted Ladies! They are, in my opinion, one of the most beautiful pieces of SF culture you can see (and take a photo with)! I always loved swinging by with friends who are from out of town and sitting in the park for a bit, and enjoying the nice breezy day. 

Parking can get a difficult but I've always found it on the side streets. If you're patient, you can find a spot! The grassy area is rather crowded but you'll be able to find a spot for someone to take your "Full House" photo. Just don't get too up close and personal with the houses as people do live in them.
author: Christine W.

description:
This is better than Full House.

I knocked off a star because it can get crowded on the park w/ some crazy/eccentric people.
author: Fifi C.

description:
Well worth climbing up two, three hills to find this! Gorgeous and easy to spot with the amount of people taking photos and squealing about them. They're right across from Alamo Square Park, which is awesome to check out and lay on the grass staring at the houses. 

I'm going to use the Detour app to take a tour and learn more about them. But enjoying the Painted Ladies and laying in the sun with blue skies above is more than enough for now. Glad I decided to visit this fun, cool tourist spot!
author: Liz B.

description: Gorgeous historic homes! I loved visiting this location, although it was pretty busy but we were able to get our photos in. I loved seeing how interested everyone was in these homes. Great experience and the day was perfect, definitely will go back.
author: Gabby M.

description:
One of my favorite tourist spots. I love the architecture, detail, and pastel colors. Made more famous from TV Shows such as Full House. I overheard that the architect lived in the far left home. 

I walked from a BART station to City Hall to Alamo Square to The Full House House to Japantown and back to Civic Center BART station. It is possible if you have the time and good health to walk miles. It is a nice walk through Hayes Valley and a bit uphill. I enjoy seeing the other Victorian homes in the neighborhoods. 

I am not sure if there is a time of day when tourists will not be in your photos. Maybe a rainy day. Early in the morning may be quieter, but may also be foggy. For picture enthusiasts, consider the lighting. SF is usually foggy. Low light shows more detail. Blue skies are great , but cast shadows on the homes. I bet you can get great sunset photos if you can time it right. I think the best sunsets are September and October. I got great Pier 39 sunsets in Oct before. 

Thank you city of SF for adding the green grass so people can have a picnic there. There is a playground for the kids. A lot of space on the hill at Alamo Square to relax and enjoy the view.
author: Julie S.

description: This was definitely on my bucket list since I grew up watching Full House as a kid. Take a picture across the street from the park to get all 7 houses in one picture. The hill facing the houses is also nice to just sit and hang out. There is a public restroom at the park if needed.
author: Lanha T.

description:
I had one day to explore San Fran and this was one of those spots that I knew I could get to easily. I grew up watching Full House and always dreamed of lying in the park for a picnic enjoying this beautiful view and the lovely and iconic homes that come with it. I couldn't help but skip up the path singing, "everywhere you look, everywhere you go, there's a heart, a hand to hold on to..." 

There was a small crowd but since it was only about 9am, it wasn't too bad at all. I was in awe with these homes and this street and got lost in my imagination, wondering what it would be like to grow up here. After getting a look up close, I took a stroll through Alamo Square so I could get an even better view of the Painted Ladies and the beautiful cityscape behind them. To my delight, there was even a coffee truck up at the top of the so I was able to grab a cold brew and sit in the grass and enjoy the view. 

If you're in SF I highly suggest you stop by the Painted Ladies. The nostalgia alone is enough to send your heart to the moon and back. If you didn't grow up watching Full House like I did, then the view is what you're coming for. It really is awesome seeing these colorful homes nestled in a cute neighborhood with the SF skyline behind them. It's pretty special.
author: Jayme H.

description: There isn't much to review- they're privately owned homes and really, all you can do is STARE at them, which is enough if you're a tourist (like me) looking for all the picture worthy spots in SF. No but really, the houses are stunning! The entire neighborhood is. I parked and walked around admiring the houses nearby, amazing. We don't have homes like these in Miami so I had to lol. The view at night with the city lit up behind the painted ladies is spectacular. Make sure to go high up on the hill til you can see the buildings in the view behind the homes!
author: Stephanie F.

description:
Whatever happened to predictability. The milkman, the paperboy, evening tv? How did I get to living here? Somebody tell me please! Of course the Full House theme song will be playing on repeat in your head when you arrive here... embrace it, feel your inner Tanner. 

So, of course I was obviously obsessed with Full House and again of course I had to make a stop and check out the beautiful Victorian houses. 

We got lucky and booked our hotel about 2-3 min walking distance so we were lucky. We grabbed some sandwiches from a coffee shop then we headed here to sit and watch the beautiful view.

Having lunch with the Tanners was our slogan for the day. Loved it here! The view was gorgeous. My suggestion is being your fancy camera, a blanket, jacket, and some food and just embrace your inner Tanner.
author: Trinh V.

description:
WHO: Me and seven girls - spending the weekend in Northern Cali!

WHAT: Celebrating our favorite, Chelsey F!

WHEN: Longer than I want to admit - but within the past few years!

WHERE: The famously beautiful, Full House favorite, San Fran staple, The Painted Ladies!

Because all 8 of us were determined to set foot in this little park overlooking the city, we set out for a morning of television homes! First stop was The Painted Ladies - who are absolutely gorgeous! Our uber dropped us right out front, to which we ran up the hill (in true Full House style!) and saw it's glory! The park boasts one of the best views of the city, is free and the perfect spot for a picnic!

Definitely worth a stop!
author: Katie F.

description:
The family picnic in the opening credits of Full House was right across the street in Alamo Square.
The painted ladies are Victorian and Edwardian houses and buildings repainted, starting in the 1960s, in three or more colors that embellish or enhance their architectural details. The term was first used for San Francisco Victorian houses by writers Elizabeth Pomada and Michael Larsen in their 1978 book Painted Ladies.
author: Gerald H.

description:
Ahhh..  If you're my age, you grew up on "Full House" and never in my life would I think I'd see the houses during the introduction...  Meet "The Painted Ladies".  So, being I'm a big ole' idiot at times, I clicked YouTube on my phone and found the Full House Intro music, played that awesome tune, and skipped down the grass like a kid in a candy store..  Lol.  My wife was so embarrassed she wouldn't even skip with me!  For better or worse I thought???  I even thought I heard Uncle Joey say, "Cut It Out!"  Lol..  Really cool to see those houses.  They stand out like a sore thumb!   So, if you're a fan of Full House or had a crush on Rebecca like we all did as kids, you must visit the Painted Ladies.  And since I know you all are trying to sing the lyrics, here they are..  You're welcome :-)

(Ahhh, ahhh, ahhh, ahhh)
 Whatever happened to predictability
 The milkman, the paperboy, evening TV
 How did I get delivered here
 Somebody tell me, please
 This old world's confusing me

 With clouds as mean as you've ever seen
 Ain't a bird who knows your tune.
 Then a little voice inside you whispers,
 Kid don't sell your dreams, so soon

 (Chorus:)
 Everywhere you look
 (Everywhere you look)
 There's a heart
 (There's a heart)
 A hand to hold onto
 Everywhere you look
 (Everywhere you look)
 There's a face
 Of somebody who needs you
 Everywhere you look

 When you're lost out there
 and you're all alone,
 A light is waiting
 to carry you home.
 Everywhere you look
 Everywhere you look
 (doop-a-dee-ba-ba-dow)
author: Scott V.

description:
There are no finer ladies in San Francisco than the Painted Ladies.

If you grew up watching the TV show "Full House", you will recognize these ladies from the opening credits of the TV show. Not only are they stunning but also beautiful.

Take the time to sit at the park across the street and admire their beauty. I am sure they wont mind that you take a few pictures while your at it.
author: Glenn A.

description:
While this seemed like a bit of a "tourist trap", we really enjoyed our visit!  The park is quite lovely - there are great views of the Painted Ladies and the city of San Francisco as a whole.  This is also a great place to bring a picnic and it's fun to sit and eat while watching the dogs play in the dog park.

Plus, of course, the Painted Ladies are great!  Growing up watching Full House, it was cool to see them in real life.
author: Kathryn M.

description: Wow !!! What a setting and one of you, and especially impressive now that I realize how the weather there is often a terrible and foggy and you would not have a view of downtown or the Gardens at all. Now that I see other peoples photos how terribly it turned out for them I'm so happy we were there on a good day,Six days ago the weather was spectacular and warm and 25 Celsius and we really enjoyed this beautiful park with a great view of both downtown and the painted ladies even though neither of us have ever watched that stupid show full house. I know that's the reason why this area is so famous but we were just there to soak up the history and other culture... Even though I wasn't alive during that time my favourite music is hippy music from the late 60s so it was nice to hang out in the very famous Haight Ashberry area and understanding the amazing history of these stunning Victorian houses and the care that the owners areObviously caring for their properties both their gardening and their outstanding paint jobs. Thank you so much. Just gorgeous.
author: Julian L.

description:
Fun little tourist spot! There is free 2-hour street parking, so it's easy to come hang out at the park, or just take your picture and explore the surrounding area (Salt and Straw is within walking distance!) 
We ended up walking around the park and enjoyed seeing all of the dogs on the other side.
author: Samantha S.

description: Literally walked in a circle at Alamo Square looking for the Painted Ladies houses and realized I had actually walked past the houses twice. I guess I imagined a different scene, a little bit more wow a little less, where are these houses? I expected bold colors, a hard to miss spot but to be honest throughout my walk to get here from Bernal Heights, I passed tons of Victorian style homes with brighter colors that had a bigger wow factor. Once I realized once I had walked past what I came here for I thought it was cool for a minute, snapped a photo or five and went on my way. I thought the park was cooler than the actual Full House, houses. I watched Full House throughout my entire childhood and so this was a place I definitely did not want to miss but it was just eh for me. I guess I was expecting Michelle DJ and Stephanie to be on the grass with their picnic blanket but they weren't. Definitely come here, definitely check it out, definitely take a picture with a caption like, Whatever happened to predictability, just like I did and then be on your way. Spend time in the park, the trees were amazing to look at. Four stars though, because, Joey and Danny and Uncle Jesse and Aunt Becky, you know? Love Full House.
author: Samantha S.

description: This park was lovely, the established trees and gardens we're beautiful and well cared for. There were so many fragrant plants and flowers the air smelled so fresh even in the midst of the city. The homes we're gorgeous but I was sad to see the empty spaces where homes had been torn down. I hope they keep to the same aesthetic when putting in new buildings.
author: Ivy L.

description: The only people giving this 1 star are angry neighbors. Best time to visit is early morning or evening. Plan accordingly.
author: E E.

description:
I'm going to assume that most people visit The Painted Ladies because of FULL HOUSE. Yeah, me too. But, it was quite a disappointment. I didn't see anything 'special' about these houses. You can find these types of houses anywhere in SF. The park across the street isn't all that either. This place seems to attract a bunch of hipsters though. IMO, overrated.

On another note, a man took off his clothes nearby me and casually changed into a fishnet underwear. He was dancing and shaking his thing. Andddd no one around him seemed to mind. Ohhhh San Francisco, where you can be as free as you want to be. As for me, the seen cannot be unseen. My poor innocent eyes are now tainted. :'(
author: Jen N.

description:
"Everywhere you look, everywhere you go
There's a heart, there's a heart, A hand to hold on to. 
Everywhere you look, everywhere you go 
There's a face, of Somebody who needs you.
When you're lost out there and you're all alone 
A light is waiting to carry you home, 
Everywhere you look....." 
This is me singing the Full House theme song while visiting the The Painted Ladies. 
 I am so happy I got to see the Full House House in reality, a dream that came true.I grew up watching Full House during the late 80s - mid 90s. I loved Full House and re-runs on Nickelodeon made my kids love the show too. 

Before our trip to San Fran., my cousin mentioned to give her a list of where we would like to go, the kids already had this on the list as their 1st choice. My cousin who lives in Daly City, had never been to The Painted Ladies. I am surprised, but glad, that we could experienced it together.

The Painted Ladies is the Full House House, located across of Alamo park. We picked up sandwiches for a picnic lunch at Alamo Park. We found a parking spot close to the park. Of course, we took our tons of pictures. I could see the expressions on my kids' face, they were so happy, makes me a happy momma!! 

The Painted Ladies is a must on the list, when visiting San Fran. esp. if you are a Full House Fan. Now I will cherish the memories I have here with my family. I am happy to cross this off my list and now time to watch Full House on Netflix!

#116/100/2017
author: Judy C.

description: I did not intent on checking this out, but I happen to get lost and parked right in front of these buildings. When I opened my map, I saw the painted ladies were right next to me. So I got out and walked around the park and shot some pics. Yes, I watched the show because my sister watched it. I never understood TV shows or vegetating in front of a screen... until the internet came around.
author: Julio H.

description: I love this spot! Maybe it's because I grew up watching Full House. Or because it's so quintessentially San Francisco. Either way, it's an SF staple for sure!
author: Jessi J.

description:
Decided to walk from Haight and Ashbury after lunch... its about a mile from the main street ... 

Note very hilly ... SF is known for this so go in comfy shoes 

The view of these beautiful Vintage ladies is magnificent... the whole ambience and backdrop of the Ladies is breathtaking... never gets old

Downfall... popular tourist destination sooooo your photo op is slim to none ... 

Being a local to the bay I enjoy the hillside picnics and views

Only gave it a 4.5 because of how jampacked it gets
author: Cathy C.

description: I was so excited to see this attraction because this was where the opening theme of Full House was filmed. However, I was a bit disappointed as there wasn't much more to the tourist spot except for the four little houses. The houses are pretty in that they are Victorian-style homes and have different colors and all. There is a little grassy hill across from the homes overlooking the houses where people can just hang out. Still, it was a little sketchy as there was trash everywhere and quite a few people hanging out and smoking.
author: Brittany E.

description: Although you can't go inside them, as they're real houses with real people living inside, these pastel Victorian beauties are the quintessential West Bay architectural statement. When viewed from Alamo Square Park across the way, you'll have the entire West Bay skyline as a backdrop. Even if it wasn't made famous by "Full House," this would be the perfect picture point any day. So go ahead, whip out your phones and put all those pictures on Instagram!
author: Vincent L.

description:
Sitting at Alamo Square will give you one of the best views of the city. It's not overcrowded like Dolores Park so it's a great place to have a picnic and take in the view of these iconic houses + the city. I feel bad for the people that live in these houses though! There are always tourists taking photos on their property.

PS this is NOT the Full House house.
author: Tiffany T.

description:
This was a great experience while I visited SF. We visited at about 1 in the afternoon and there was a parking spot on the street right in front of the painted ladies! Enjoyed the nostalgia of watching Full House and the park across the street was full of a friendly crowd and their pets. 

Although it was great, I wish there was a plaque to give some history on the painted ladies.
author: Landon G.

description:
Something to see when you come to San Francisco for the first time! We played tourist for the day on Labor Day. I have lived in the Bay Area almost my whole life and have never been to this place unless seen from 'Full House' the TV series! 

'Painted Ladies' term was used for all the Victorian homes that were colored in different colors in a row. It was to show the agricultural details of the homes.

These popular Victorian homes can been seen from the Alamo Square Park. Many sit on the grass and just sit and view the Victorian homes with the SF city in the background. A must come visit or at least, be on your bucket list! It sure is as a beautiful site! [96/100]
author: Edna G.

description: Love how our photos turned out, this really is gorgeous. We parked at the park across the way and went up the small hill and got these shots. And then the kids played at the playground after. We went in March when the weather was chilly in SF but these views are breathtaking especially of the city.
author: Daisy T.

description: The painted ladies how I never thought I would see you besides on tv. This place holds a special place in my heart because I grew up watch Full House and now Fuller House.
author: Mane S.

description:
Located just across the street from Alamo Square park!

Beautiful & colorful buildings that have become an iconic symbol of Full House the tv show.

Many tourists visit this area to snap a photo with the beautiful ladies in the background.

It is a must see when you are in San Francisco.
author: Nathalie M.

description:
What can I say? This well known landmark near the Alamo Square has it all that many residents and tourists are heading this spot called, the "Painted Ladies." These Victorian and Edwardian styled houses were built between 1849 and 1915 which makes these houses a place called home until the disastrous 1906 earthquake destroyed the portions of the houses; few of them were survived as of today. Finally, in the 1960s, Butch Kardum, a local San Francisco painter and artist had a vision to make these houses a splash of color, and it did successfully to make it more 20th Century pop art material and classic atmosphere combined.

There's nothing much about the Painted Ladies' houses although it was a magnificent experience to visit there for the very first time while exploring San Francisco on 4/29/2017. The view while walking on the incline hill of Alamo Square is simply breathtaking which you can see tons of skyscraper buildings of the 20th and 21st Centuries especially gorgeous view on Golden Gate Bridge and the 2nd half of San Francisco Oakland Bay Bridge combined from sunrise to sunset.

If you want to explore The Painted Ladies, parking can be quite challenging to park. You can park at the nearby surface street parking if it's available. Alternatively, you can also ride a bike, walk, ride sharing or public transportation easier without the hassles and gimmicks.

In the end, The Painted Ladies is the most spectacular and historical landmark place that I've ever discovered and visited for this signature place in San Francisco! Perfect for all ages from young to old! My rating: 5 solid stars.
author: William L.

description:
Very nice, super busy, and lots of place to hang out at the park. It's just a very nice atmosphere! 
Note:  be careful of the hills on muddy days....I slid down a hill and I typically don't fall gracefully.
author: Julina V.

description:
Anyone who has seen pretty much any show or anything that is about San Francisco or that takes place there has seen some type of shot of the Painted Ladies.  They are beautiful in photographs but from looking just across the street while in Alamo Square, the ladies are unspeakably beautiful.  The homes themselves are like pieces of art and it is easy to see why there is a fascination with them.  While sitting in the park, it is like looking at living Victorian art across the street.  I could easily have spent a lot more time at this location.

Parking can be a little difficult in the area.  After driving around for a little bit, we got pretty lucky and found parking just around the corner from the Painted Ladies.  Just be sure to watch the street signs for parking rules and make sure you don't park anywhere that requires a resident permit.

Make sure to take a couple pictures in front of the houses from up on the hill in the park.  It is really touristy but also really cool!
author: Angela D.

description:
A tourist must see for SF and/or fans of the 90s sitcom Full House. 

In person maybe they aren't as grand as you'd first imagined but still neat none the less. 

The park across the street where everyone stands to grab their photo is ok but again not what I think most imagine based on the opening credits of FH. 

Bring a blanket if you want to sit and hangout for a little while. 

And if you like you can even take a semi longish but nice walk down to the Mrs. Doubtfire house.
author: Amanda H.

description:
Well known landmark for Full House show.

Can't believe we have been close to this area so many times.

Yup we hiked here the most recent time from that fabulous French bakery.

Didn't have to deal with finding parking so that was convenient.

Will we come back? Maybe. Only if it's sunny. Possibly to get an even better landscape shot. Maybe this week? What a fabulous idea!
author: Karen K.

description:
Known by some as the "Full House" houses (shown in the opening credits of the original show). Be sure to walk up onto the adjoining hill for a full picture shot. If you can, recommend grabbing a bite to eat and picnicking on the lawn and just enjoying the day. Otherwise, this is just a quick landmark visit before you head off to another site to see. Most of the tourist buses should have this as one of their landmark locations.

Interesting tidbit: in order to be an official "painted lady" house, there must be a minimum of 3 (although, I've heard it's actually 5) different colors used on the exterior decor of a Victorian style home.
author: Amber H.

description: We were staying a couple of blocks from the Painted Ladies on this stay in SF. I've never had the urge to visit them as there are many immaculately presented Victorian weatherboard homes in SF. We strolled around at about 5.30pm there was still many people sitting on the grass hill in Alamo Square. Nice views of the city behind the Painted Ladies. Yes touristy but was nice to see them & there certainly wasn't a mass of people at this time.
author: Lyndal G.

description: When I sat down at Alamo Square Park, I jokingly stated I had been waiting for this moment since '98, but it was 100% true. I was feelin a bit nostalgic and grew up watching Full House so I really enjoyed this part of my trip. The park is a great place to have a picnic or just sit around and people watch. For all the tourists out there---this area is a nice 20ish minute walk to Dolores park /bi rite icecream so definitely visit both these places =D
author: Maysa M.

description:
1 of the most overrated spots in San Fran.

It's a row of houses "painted ladies" style, but you can find these types of houses in a lot of spots. No need to go to this specific spot....
author: Michelle B.

description:
It's iconic and an obvious must see place in San Francisco. I love Victorian houses, it's always been my dream to own and live in one. I just love the strong character and craftsmanship of these homes. The Painted ladies are occupied by people (owners) so of course be respectful of that. 

There is a park right in front of the homes that is unfortunately under construction right now so I couldn't really get a wide angled photo like I wanted at a higher view point but that's ok. They're of course plenty of houses around San Francisco that are just as, if not more, beautiful than this row but those other houses were NOT featured on a popular family sitcom! I grew up watching Full House so this made me smile knowing I've been there :)
author: Jevonnie B.

description: Yes, these are the houses in the background of the Full House picnic (in Alamo Square) or the pictures you have seen on postcards! These row of houses are cute, colorful, Victorian, and quintessentially SF. They have a mock-Painted Ladies in Syracuse, New York that are also multi-floor homes connected together of various colors but they are architecturally not as interesting and grand as the Painted Ladies in SF. The grassy area in front of this spot is surprisingly hillier than I expected. Picnicking there is harder than Bob Saget made it seem. Don't go too close to the houses because people do live in them! This isn't a "must-see" site for first-timers or tourists here, but it's definitely worth visiting if you're a Full House fan or want to picnic on a really hilly hill that isn't Dolores Park.
author: Brenda L.

description:
I came here with my friend about a month ago. It's a good photo opportunity but can get crowded, and a lot of trees actually obscure the view of the houses. 

But if you're in the area and walking around, it's worth at least looking at them.
author: Merisenda A.

description: We walked all the way across the city to check these out and it was worth it. Alamo park across the street is very pretty although there were a lot of people as well.
author: Karolina T.

description: It was nice to see the Full House theme house in person. My family and I really enjoyed the park & the view of the city from there.
author: Mia P.

description: Came here to have a picnic around sunset and felt like I was in the opening credits of Full House.
author: Shama P.

description:
Such a beautiful sight....picture perfect on a bright sunny day. 

Nice neighborhood with wonderful people...

A must see when in sfo....great architecture and work of art.
author: Jon L.

description:
If you're a tourist and missing your furry best friend, Alamo Square Park where you view the houses has a dog park. It was a pleasant surprise. 

We actually almost skipped coming to see the Painted Ladies. But at the last minute took an Uber over, and we're glad we did. Pictures don't do them justice. There are plenty of similar looking houses throughout SFO, but the way they are situated alone, with the park right there and skyline in the background is pretty awesome. 

Checkout the Bean Bag Cafe just a short walk away for a good bite to eat too!
author: Adam R.

description:
The "iconic" Painted Ladies... 

Sure, they are lovely homes with their Victorian details.  And the park across the street is large and green and I totally see why the Tanner's* spent so much time there. 

But I was a little underwhelmed by the ladies.  Honestly, I sort of expected them to be brighter and bolder.  The ladies I saw were muted and a little sad.

Is it still worth visiting? Yeah, it's worthy of a photo or two but overall you don't need to spend a lot of time here.


*Obligatory Full House reference.
author: Alyssa R.

description: This was a cool spot to check out. You can get pictures of the famous House's and also an amazing view of the city. Parking is tight and you may need to be dropped off or park somewhere else and walk over to this area.
author: Ron V.

description: really cute place to stop and get a few pictures, look and the landscape, and quote some Full House. It's a cute park to walk around too, lots of other beautiful buildings, and there's a dog park! I would suggest bringing food to picnic or a game to play, otherwise you'll only be there for a few minutes before you get bored
author: Logan L.

description: These groups of homes are  so beautiful. I wanted to see the full house house but the producers of the show just purchased it and was in the middle of restoring it to look like the original full house with the red door. That would not make for a beautiful background so we decided to come see the beautiful famous painted ladies. And it was. We also happens to find a golden retriever as we were taking pictures. Of course we had to borrow how for the pictures. Thank your George (his owner)for letting us. Oreos him for a little bit. This was a very quiet and beautiful park. A great place for a picnic or even to walk around and get exercise. Idk why it's called the painted ladies is actually a group of painted houses.
author: Ciara N.

description:
"Everywhere you look..." there is a Painted Lady in San Francisco! What is a Painted Lady, you ask? Why, it's a Victorian-style house with at least three colors - any three colors, take your pick. 

Now, THESE Painted Ladies are the most famous because of Full House fame. Yes, if you stand in Alamo Square Park across the street, you can take a picture from the same angle where Joey, Jesse and the Tanner family had a picnic. 

Note that these multi-million dollar homes are private property, so be respectful and don't walk up the stoops. Also, tour buses larger than eight passengers are not allowed on this street, so they will drop you off on a side street to walk over and get a photo op.
author: Katie U.

description: I was excited to go here during my trip to the Bay Area and made sure this was one of the places to go to while here. The painted ladies was disappointing. The colors were boring on the houses. I was expecting vibrant colorful homes. Very cookie cutter. Parking is limited. There is a park across the street that people hang out at taking pictures. Glad I crossed this off the bucket list but will not make an effort to come back.
author: Gabriela H.

description: Lovely neighbourhood filled with old victorian/edwardian houses. Lovely to walk around and admire the beautiful architecture. Finally made it to Alamo Sq where the painted ladies are located. Beautiful place.
author: Heliana M.

description: Beautiful stop that's worth it to see if you're in San Francisco. We walked from our hotel Sunday morning (25 minute stroll) and had about 20 other park goers there. Great place for photos, lunch, relaxing, etc. You get a view of the whole city too, it's very scenic. Cross the street and get up close to the homes as well, there's no bad angle here. Totally unique and a beautiful architectural spot to add to your trip. If you love sightseeing and getting that great travel photo, this is a quintessential San Fran spot.
author: Jenna K.

description:
DOV: 11/12/16 
3rd stop | 10 AM-10:30 AM 

If this wasn't on the way to my next destination, I probably wouldn't visit here. It might be a fun place to visit after they fix up Alamo Square/Park, since right now it's huge patches of dry weed and fences blocking certain parts.

No pretty angle to take this with the background- you're just gonna have to photoshop the heck out of it! 

TBH, all the other homes in SF look like this...I kept asking my friend "are we there yet? is it this one?!" along the way here....see how easy it is to mistaken?

Ample parking, quiet neighborhood, but close enough to the hustle of the city.
author: Hurjane V.

description:
The painted ladies are Victorian and Edwardian houses and buildings painted in three or more colors that embellish or enhance their architectural details.This is a landmark of the San Francisco.

One of the houses were used for the TV series, full house. A popular tourist destination. 

Parking : street parking but it can difficult to search for an empty spot.
author: Ashi C.

description: Look, they're a short row of pretty buildings with a great view beyond, yet they're not worth a special trip over there.  If they're near where you'll be visit!  If you need to make a special trip over there, don't bother.  It's not a very important destination.  It's like, Ok here they are, now let's go.
author: Scott H.

description:
These beautiful homes are displayed in the opening credits of the tv series Full House. Some people think one of these houses is the home used in the show. The actual Full House Home is on a different street.

These homes are directly across from the Alamo Square (a park). 

Here are some tips to consider:
1. Parking is free all around the park if you can find a spot.
2. The best picture taking is on the Alamo Square on top of the hill directly in front of the Painted Ladies.
3. Nearest public restroom is at Alamo Square facing the Painted ladies.
author: Sam N.

description: I knew all about Full House! I think it's so cool knowing I got to be somewhere a show was filmed for TV. Must see even if you've never watched it! I don't watch TV but thought the houses were so cool. I wonder if anyone(that was in the film) lives in, rents or visits them often?cool, historical spot.
author: Alexis G.

description:
I grew up watching Full House, so I knew that if I were to ever visit San Francisco, I would go check out the painted ladies.

The houses are beautiful, it's like I was looking at a postcard! I love the Victorian feel that they have, and their pastel colors just added extra umph to everything.

I was lucky enough to find a parking spot right in front of one of the houses, so I just walked across the street to the park to get in my photos. But you can park all around Alamo Square.

This place can get crowded, but regardless, it's still nice to pay a visit. 

While I visited, the majority of the park was closed for renovations. They left a bit of park open for tourists to take photos, but everything else was closed off.
author: Michelle T.

description: Definitely lived up to my every expectations. It's as beautiful in person as it is in photos.
author: Glenelle S.

description:
The Painted Ladies is a popular tourist spot made famous by the tv sitcom show Full House. The classic victorian style design still holds strong despite the sudden existence of newly built dwellings around the area. Street parking was fairly easy to find and you can't help but admire how the architecture and colorful accents are still visible and maintained by the owners. 

The Painted Ladies are located across from the Alamo Square Park on Steiner Street. There is a nice hill for a picturesque moment or simply sneak in a selfie. Alamo Square Park was currently going through renovations and the grasses were gone. I recommend staying on the park grounds for any photo opportunities. Depending on the time of day, the tourist crowd may prevent a clear picture of the Painted Ladies. From experience, the best times to go are early to mid morning or during sunset. Locals are even nice enough to offer to take your picture in front of the homes.
author: Karlo G.

description:
These iconic houses were very much worth visiting in person. There is plenty of street parking in the area. The houses are across from Alamo Square which is where the Tanners were having a picnic in the opening music of Full House. It does not look like that anymore though. The grass is flattened and yellow and there is a bit  of construction so a lot of the area is closed off. You can still climb on part of the hill and grab some pictures of the homes. There were maybe 20-30 people doing that when I visited on a Monday afternoon. 
Along with the painted ladies, there are several similar and also gorgeous homes in the surrounding area with the Victorian and Edwardian styles. A few of them are under construction. If you don't park immediately next to them, you may have to walk up and down a fairly steep hill. If you're from a flat area, you may feel the burn in your legs.
author: Jasmin F.

description: Beautiful park and beautiful houses to gaze upon. It's got a wonderful atmosphere at the park and the houses in the surrounding area are such an Aesthetic. Definitely a place I would go to for picnics and such.
author: Denisa P.

description:
I don't get it? 

It's literally just a couple houses next to each other. You can walk around anywhere in San Fran and basically see this?? 
The park next to them is nice though. Gives you a pretty good view of the city and if you like dogs there's a handful of people showing off their breeds in the park. Bark bark

As a side note, there's plenty of other places (houses) you could see around the city that are absolutely gorgeous if you pay attention.
author: Dan L.

description:
I was born in SF, raised in the East Bay and I still have never really seen the most "touristy" areas of the Bay. On Memorial Day, the family was out in SF because our kids wanted to visit Japantown. We finished with going there by 2PM. We were sitting in the car and I said, "We need to go see the Full House, house". 

I searched on here to see how far we were from the place and it's actually only a four minute drive from Japantown. When I realized that, I was determined to go! 

Now, I realize that this is NOT the Full House, house. But as everyone else has mentioned in their reviews, this is the backdrop in the opening credits. I still couldn't believe after living here for so long, I've never seen these houses. 

Alamo Square Park was closed for renovation when we were there. So we couldn't stand up on the hill to get a good view of the houses with the SF skyline in the background. There were lots of people taking pictures and looking at the houses, so I didn't feel silly taking pictures. Even my boyfriend was excited and singing the Full House theme song as he was taping. Parking is limited, but luckily we found a spot right on the corner at the stop sign right past the homes. 

The houses are gorgeous and it was really neat to see them in person. There are so many great landmarks within the Bay that are so popular worldwide. It's our family's mission now to take day trips to different places throughout the Bay that we haven't visited yet.
author: Rachel S.

description:
This popular 710-720 Steiner Street across Alamo Square is a true San Francisco attraction represents the beauty and colorful architecture of the city.

Painted Ladies or Postcard Row is a term for American architectural for Edwardian and Victorian houses or buildings using three or more colors to enhance their architectural details. This place also made famous for the home of the Tanners in Full House. Also a really pretty place to watch see the San Francisco skyline. It makes such a pretty picture with these pastel houses in the background. Picnic and lounge in Alamo Park to admire the beauty of this attraction! Even being a local I love driving in this neighborhood catching a glimpse of this pretty picture! Even before I lived here the symbol of these Victorian houses made me think of this beautiful city where my heart is!
author: Maria M.

description: This place is a must when in San Fran. I'm a super tourist anywhere I go. Minus the fanny pack and selfie stick. Sometimes the peace sign is included. The first time I visited Alamo Square, I was under the impression it was also the Full House House. After a little research I found it was not. Although I did enjoy the nostalgia that comes with this view of Painted Ladies. Next trip we will do the picnic thing and recreate the opening scene of Full House.
author: Pam M.

description:
"What ever happened to predictability?"
Yes, I was singing the Full House song the entire time I was here. So many memories flooded back, so many catch phrases, so much good.
Even aside from the show, these houses are stunning! 
Multimillion dollar homes with an amazing view!
The park itself is really nice, great for a picnic & great for the kids to run around & play. 
Walk up the hill a little bit to get the best photo opportunities!
author: Phylicia K.

description: To be honest I was a little disappointed! The park was closed off for construction and we wasted a lot of time looking for parking just so we could look at some houses! If you are in town for a few days, then I would skip this tourist site and pick something a little better!
author: Keisha K.

description:
Something to see, but there are better spots.  Fine for a quick stop.  However, at the moment there is construction going on on the viewing hill, so a big chain link fence and huge yellow earth-mover are blocking the best spots to take photos from.

Also, relative to some photos I have seen, the ladies are either sun-faded or great filters were used on their beauty-shots.  :)  The differentiation in their colors was not as great as I expected.

That said, if you walk around this neighborhood, you will see other examples of lovely Victorian and Edwardian homes that are quite vivid and beautiful in color.
author: Michele D.

description:
A well known landmark!

I didn't know that this row of Victorian houses was featured in the television show, "Full House".  I just wanted to see "The Painted Ladies" because I have seen them on postcards and paintings!  They were built in the late 1800's and have survived the Earthquake of 1906.

It's cool that these homes are still functional!  If you look carefully, you can see Downtown San Francisco in the background!  This is a great contrast of "old" and "new".

Park along Alamo Square - there is free street parking on all four sides!  Walk to the top of the hill and admire the view!  Just look for a bunch of tourists posing in front of cameras and taking selfies... that's the spot!
author: Nadine C.

description:
I've been wanting to check this row of houses out for as long as I can remember. But was I the only one who was underwhelmed? Maybe it was the fact that I chose to walk through the Haight before this and back. Maybe it was the very inclined sidewalk right before getting to the park. Who knows? Anyway, it's cool to just come and see. Everyone else had the right idea of coming there to picnic. I probably would've been in a better mood if I had food with me haha. 

I'm glad I went. I got some sketching done and snapped pictures. I feel like the houses around the park and in the neighboring blocks are much better. The view of the rest of the city was worth the walk though. Maybe I'll come back with friends and food. It was nice to sit alone and take in everything though.
author: Venna Q. T.

description:
When my sister mentioned we we going to see the Painted Ladies I had no idea what she was talking about. So I was like oh yeah sure sure. The girls just thought we were going to a little park.

Since they like watching Full House, they liked it here. They had a blast taking pictures of the Victorian style house's and themselves. They also spent half an hour arguing over which one is the actual house lol. By the way none of them are, they just came out in the credits. Since we were here early finding a place to park wasn't too bad. There is plenty of spots for you to take good pictures here.
author: Graciela P.

description: This was okay- for what it was. Overall, pretty underwhelming and not worth making a special trip for. If you're in the area though- go take a look.
author: Tara M.

description: You may think Painted Ladies is one of those overhyped San Francisco tourist locations. But honestly, it's one of the best experiences I had in San Francisco! It's a beautiful park that overlooks the homes, so it's perfect for just a light relaxing stroll through the city. Not only that, but it's so picturesque and perfect for a group photo when you're traveling.
author: Hanna J.

description: Wish I could say I enjoyed them more than I did! The painted ladies were sadly underwhelming. I had to ask someone else there to confirm that I was even at the right place. Maybe if the park was open I might've had a better experience. I'll try again the next time I'm in town. Hopefully then Alamo square park will be open & the ladies a little bit more cheerful.
author: Ashley B.

description:
Full House!!!

If you watched Full House, you know these houses from the credits. I get those flashback memories when I come here. 

Be respectful to the residents of the houses. People do live there.

Free parking.

Best view is from Alamo Park.
author: Kevin W.

description: Although iconic, if you truly enjoy the architecture, simply walking around that neighborhood yields even better examples of Victorian and Edwardian style homes. Nevertheless, there is a great view of San Fransisco from the top of the hill in the park directly in front of the painted ladies. Unfortunately that park is currently under construction and fenced off.
author: Peter N.

description:
One of the best photo opportunities in SF. Lombard street would also be a good bet since it is widely recognized. These houses are so popular probably for so many reasons: Alamo Square park across the street gives some green to the area, the beautiful views behind the 6 houses, and of course the architecture of the houses themselves. 

They are beautifully painted and very well kept. They have been made even more popular by being in the public view so often in popular culture. Once you know them you will see representations of them once in a while. At the Greenhouse San Leandro Mc Donalds, for example, there is wallpaper of them in 2 tones that can be recognized just by the shadow outlines of them.

Its worth a $15 Uber if you come from a different country just to see these. There are popular tour buses that are a better value hitting all the tourists spots in just a matter of hours.

Take your photo and look forward to coming back in 10 years for another photo in the same spot. This place wont change much I doubt. They built it well more than 100 years ago right the first time and its here to stay.
author: Stefan T.

description:
Just so cottdamm BEAUTIFUL... No matter if it's foggy or sunny. Best viewed from up on Alamo Square Park, with the San Francisco skyline in the distance. The Painted Ladies are a victorian set of masterpieces. Yes, it's super touristy but this block of Steiner Street is quintessential San Francisco.

And if you're not humming the Full House TV show theme, then I dont know what to say to you... "Everywhere you look...."
author: Chuck D.

description: Yeah....only if you remember/care about Full House.  Maybe if you happen to be James Bond you could fold your car up into a suitcase and take it with you because you ain't parking around here.  Otherwise you'd better bus/lyft it.  There's not really anything here besides some grass.  Good to check off the old bucket list but beyond that I dunno (shrug).
author: Herman T.

description:
Niece wanted to see this site...so off we went.  Well cared for houses with a joy about them.  Parking can be difficult. 

Nice park to enjoy picnic across the street.
She enjoyed the afternoon, so success!
author: Nene R.

description:
The Painted Ladies on Steiner Street between Fulton and Hayes Streets are iconic because of their place in the opening crawl on Full House. The best place to view the houses are across the street on Steiner Street from Alamo Square Park. The Painted Ladies is often confused for being the place where the Full House house is actually located. In reality, the house that was used as the façade of the house that the Tanners lived in on the show is 1709 Broderick Street, San Francisco, CA 94115 which is a mile northwest of the Painted Ladies.


If you are visiting San Francisco and looking for recommendations, feel free to message me through Yelp and I can share my itinerary, which includes my Yelp reviews. The information for an electronic copy can also be found in the link via my Yelp profile.
author: Patrick W.

description:
I've lived next door to famous Postcard Row for over 2 decades, long before it became a "must see" on the top places to visit in San Francisco. 

(Hayes Valley was not the trendy neighborhood it is now; not so many years ago it was a crime-plagued area.)

Recently I've had a few visitors ask me "Why is this block special?" Some of them shrug as if to say, "Eh, that's it?"

The Painted Ladies are special not only because of the spectacular, unobstructed, panoramic view of the downtown skyline that drops down behind them but also because of the contrast between old and new San Francisco. 

The Kavanaugh houses - the architect lived in the first house, the only one whose steps face his rose garden - survived the 1906 earthquake and fire like many homes in the Western Addition thankfully did (except for ones later bulldozed by the city in an offensive racist bid claiming "eminent domain") that ravaged huge swaths of the city, particularly SOMA and the Mission whose closely built, wood homes went up like tinder.

Built in the late 1880s, these Painted Ladies may have changed hands a few times over the past 20 years (the first and last homes within the past 3 years) but the history remains.

I've been inside four of the seven homes and the ornate, hand-carved wood, stained glass windows and other Victorian details are all in place. 

Scores of movies have featured the houses (The Dead Pool, the remake of Invasion of the Body Snatchers with Donald Sutherland, Junior) many TV shows except for the one everyone thinks features the Painted Ladies (the Full House house is actually at 1709 Broderick St.), dozens of commercials from Advair to California Tourism.

It's wonderful to live next door to so much history!
author: Jennifer O.

description: I am so lucky that my friend lives nearby. She took me here on a Saturday morning and found parking less than a block away from The Painted Ladies. They looked like normal houses when we drove past it, but once I reached Alamo Square, I can kind of see how these houses are so iconic. We took a couple of photos in front, it's definitely a tourist attraction but worth checking out. I definitely felt nostalgic coming here, since I grew up watching Full House for a good part of my childhood. I'm glad the houses are still very much intact and standing tall.
author: Cathy M.

description: There is not that much to see but it is a historic landmark so I guess in that aspect it makes it worth a stop. I prefer the park that the ladies face more as it has a nice view of the city. It's clean and you can lounge around or even have a picnic there.
author: Shaneel R.

description:
Funny thing.  While living in Pacifica I never came here.  Now that I live elsewhere ... I play tourist all over San Francisco and love it.

Been here many times over the past five years.  Best time to photograph is dusk -- like these pics.  It gets a bit crowded but it's worth the effort for some nice shots of these beautiful Victorians.
author: Tim L.

description: Beautiful iconic houses that are in about every movie filmed in SF. Lots of street parking during the week. There is a park in front with benches to sit and admire the victorian homes. At the moment they are renovating this part of the park so its closed ofd but the back part is open to relax in. Full house fans have fun finding that specific house. Also another free place to hang out.
author: Theresa G.

description:
The painted ladies otherwise know as postcard row is another must see in San Fran, not just for fans of the 90's tv show full house. 

The term painted ladies comes from Victorian and Edwardian houses painted in three or more colors that enhance or embellish their architectural details.

  What a beautiful area, these house's are located right across this wide open park where you will find lots of people enjoying the sun. The park is on a hill that allows you lots of different photo angles of the surrending buildings.
 
 Also located about a 1 mile walk from 1709 Broderick Street, the house used as the Tanner home in the tv show full house.
author: Kelly S.

description:
A famous attraction and landmark in San Francisco but it's overrated in my opinion. It was much nicer to look at pictures than be there in person. The houses weren't as colourful as depicted but I suppose to have a distinct architecture from all the other houses I've seen so far. 

It's overcrowded, tons of people there taking pictures and the park in front of it has almost no grass (mainly dirt) probably because there have been so many people taking pictures and the city just hasn't maintained the area so it makes walking around that area not feel as great.

One of my least favourite landmark of the city and its recommend going to Dolores park or twin peaks over painted ladies. There is also not much to do here besides take pictures of houses and the park in front of the houses is pretty small and dull as well.
author: Christopher L.

description: Meh.  Wasn't stellar for me, but my friends from Cincinnati seemed to find them interesting.  They're nice-looking Victorians, but I see colorful Victorians all the time in Sacramento.
author: Maggie S.

description:
The Painted Ladies.

A San Francisco landmark. 

Representative of one of the best shows of all time--Full House. 

Situated next to a pretty nice park, I believe everyone who is a fan of the show or wanting to get a dose of SF should come visit this place once in their lifetime if they happen to be free & in the area.
author: Amy C.

description: You have to stop by The Painted Ladies if you are ever in SF. For me and my boyfriend, we made 2 trips! On the first day we arrived in SF, it was sprinkling, so most of our pictures were very wet and very gloomy. Came 2 days later and the sun was out and you could see the colors of the houses come out. There are benches directly across, you can sit and contemplate life if you would like. Parking can be very difficult since it is on the street. We also ran into trouble parallel parking on a steep incline. (We are from SoCal, so we aren't very familiar with such incline in streets, lol)
author: Michelle S.

description: I grew up watching Full House! Loved the show, when I first fell in love with San Francisco...and we got there and it was so sad. The grass was dead in the park and they were doing so many renovations to the area. I hope to return and see the location back to its glory days.
author: Nicole O.

description: I admittedly fell into a tourist trap but it's okay! I'm glad that I saw it to determine for myself what the craze was all about. I think the painted ladies are nice to look at but I think the other homes in the area are more worth the trip over. There are some interesting pieces of architecture and trims that I absolutely fell in love with. If you're in the area, sure, stop by, but I wouldn't go out of my way to see them.
author: Julianne S.

description:
We have seen many attractions in SF within 4 days but these ladies are way over-rated. They are not even as colorful as in photos. You need filters to manage that bright colors. 

We were at Dolores Park and decided to walk there, about half an hour. There is kind of beautification going on across the street where you stand to take photos but for now it is only dusty soil. 

If you have time to kill, you can have a look but on a tight schedule, do not bother.
author: Ceren A.

description: You can't come to San Francisco and not see the "Painted Ladies". You see these beautiful homes in almost every computer screen saver out there. Of course that's not the only reason why you should come. The homes are nice. If you like visiting places just to look and enjoy the view, then this is for you. There's not a lot to do here, so you really have to just be the kind of person that is entertained easily. The homes in the area are also nice to look at. My boyfriend and I spent the afternoon in Japantown and walked to the Painted Ladies. It's a nice 12-18 minute walk. Good exercise, with a nice view at the end. Currently they are still renovating Alamo Park, but there's room to climb the hill and snap a picture. Don't feel like walking? We took a Lyft. There were lots of them in the area.
author: Christal C.

description:
One of the first historic landmarks we checked out since it was walking distance from where we were staying.

The Good:
Definitely an iconic place to check out. The houses are gorgeous in architecture and worth taking pictures of. It helps that Full House and Fuller House has made it even more famous. Make sure you get on the hill at Alamo Square to take a good shot and you can even grab a good selfie with all the houses in the background.

The Bad:
Alamo Square is under some major construction. If you think about recreating the picnic from Full House, think again. Tons of dust and dirt going on. I don't think its going to be done for quite a while. Also, driving here can be a nightmare since parking can be a pain. You're better off walking here to enjoy everything.

Enjoy the nostalgia and sing the Full House song while you're at it.
author: Abbie C.

description:
Whatever happened to predictability? The milk man, the paper boy, evening TV! 

Yes I was one of those kids who enjoyed watching Full House.  When I was visiting the city, I knew I had to stop here to see it in person.  

I wasn't the only one for sure.  There was a multitude of visitors here for the perfect photo op in front of the painted ladies.  The large grassy area across the street is a beautiful area.  The park here has a play area for kids as well as the picturesque backdrop of San Francisco.  

If you're taking the Big Bus around, one of the stops is just a block away.  Just remember- Everywhere you look, there's a face of somebody who needs you!
author: Bethany E.

description: Another place on the tourist to do list that leaves me a little baffled.  The painted ladies are nice and its a good photo op but there are many other places in San Fran that have similarly beautiful homes.  I ended up watching the Full House opening credits when I got home and got a bit more excited and didn't regret paying a visit.
author: Monica G.

description: Fun iconic place from tv show full house. Fun park across the street and beautiful sights.
author: Carmen D.

description:
Up close, like the Full House house, I was disappointed.  But...after looking at the ladies from further away (and in some of the great pics other Yelpers took), they're way prettier and more worthy of visiting than the Full House house.

These houses are really pretty but it was hard to take a picture of all the houses being on the street (you have to go way further back) and, compared to other SF houses, these were okay.  I think the beauty comes from looking at all of them from further away.  Up close, I wasn't impressed. It's cool to see them as historical remnants of SF culture definitely takes pictures from across the street.  I liked walking here and it is pretty close to the Full House house so you can definitely explore both together.
author: Monica J.

description:
Lovely homes!

I wondered why these homes were called what it is, the Painted Ladies... It is actually a term used for "Victorian and Edwardian houses and buildings that are painted in three or more colors that enhances their architectural details."

We actually just happened to stumble in this area by accident. The first time we passed by these homes were during Super Bowl 50. It had one of the golden number 50 on Alamo Square Park. These commemorative "50's" were placed throughout San Francisco during the Super Bowl City promotion and we wanted to take a photo of one. Parking was very limited so we just zipped through this place. One of the best-known groups of "Painted Ladies" is the row of Victorian houses at 710-720 Steiner Street, across from the park. The houses, the park... the scene looked so familiar! I wanted to come back to this area and actually stop and take photos. it is probably best known for appearing in the opening montage of the sitcom "Full House" you'll recognize this area where you see the Tanner household playing soccer, running uphill, and having a picnic on Alamo Square Park towards the end of the opening theme with the Painted Ladies on the backdrop. The season ran from 1987-1995. I'm sure this block appears many times in media and professional and amateur photographs and are one of San Francisco's most photographed tourist attractions. The Victorian houses are beautiful... so San Francisco. The park was not that well maintained, nevertheless, still attracts many tourists. Pretty cool landmark!

Review #0478
author: May A.

description:
Totally anticlimactic and VERY unsafe location.  We parked for 15 minutes in front of over 100 tourists taking pictures, and our window was smashed and my 10 year old son's backpack was stolen with his lifelong favorite stuffed Curious George.  Police say there can be up to 70 break ins PER DAY in that area.  We saw 3 in the hour we dealt with our issue.

TOURISTS AVOID!!!!!
author: Jeff Z.

description: Never missed this place when come to SF. Painted ladies across Alamo Square. Nice atmosphere and weather in summer.
author: Willy T.

description:
Everywhere you look, everywhere you go
There's a heart, (There's a heart),
a hand to hold on to
Everywhere you look, everywhere you go
There's a face,
of somebody who needs you,
Everywhere you look

Haha okay, enough of the Full House theme song chorus.
Located near the Alamo Square.
Great place to have a picnic that outlook these colorful Victorian houses.
Oh, we met some tourists that were confused how they got a parking on grades ticket.
So park your car proper upon any slope!
author: Laramae E.

description:
Whatever happened to predictability?
The milkman, the paperboy, evening tv? 
How did I get to living here? 
Somebody tell me please! 
This old world's confusing me. 
With clouds as mean as you've ever seen 
Ain't a bird who knows your tune. 
Then a little voice inside you Whispers, 
Kid don't sell your dreams, so soon

Everywhere you look, everywhere you go 
There's a heart (There's a heart), a hand to hold onto. 

Everywhere you look, everywhere you go 
There's a place, of Somebody who needs you 
Everywhere you look.

When you're lost out there and you're all alone, 
A light is waiting to carry you home. 
Everywhere you look. 
Everywhere you look.
author: Aaron W.

description:
These are some beautiful houses.   If they look familiar its because they are photographed a lot.    They have been on tv (for example the opening of Full house).  They are a great photo op with a nice park across the street for better views.

The park is also a great park for a picnic with the views.  

These are some great examples of Victorians,  then its time to go,  None of the houses is open for tours,  They are still what they were built for,  peoples homes.
author: Mark B.

description:
This is one of the most iconic views of San Francisco. There is a park across the street that you can visit. This is where the iconic opening of the show Full House was filmed. Definitely a spot you would want to take a touristy picture if you're in the area. 
FYI if you're looking for something touristy, the house used for the filming of Full House's exterior shots is only about a mile down the road on Broderick st.
author: Kevin S.

description:
It was unfortunate that with the construction going on in Alamo Square, somehow seeing the Painted Ladies yesterday felt underwhelming. I was pondering whether the houses had been repainted in a drab color? but I think that maybe all the dirt from the park and people in one area somehow took away from the view. 

The houses are definitely iconic to SF and hopefully once the construction is all done in Alamo Square it will be a great place to hang out, pretend like you're in the opening scene of Full House and enjoy the pretty view.
author: Sarah S.

description: These homes have popped up everywhere on Facebook and Instagram. I grew up watching Full House and always saw these types of homes in the beginning of the show. Since I live in the Bay Area and I was feeling spontaneous, I decided to go check it out. I went here when Alamo Square Park was getting renovated across the street from the Painted Ladies homes. Totally bring a selfie stick if you have one so you can capture yourself and the picturesque beauty behind you.
author: Annette T.

description: This location was unfortunately under construction when we arrived (and it looks somewhat long term) The homes are not as bright and colorful as they seem in pictures or tv shows. There was a metal fence surrounding the perimeter and it showed in every picture. I wouldn't recommend going out of your way to visit. The park does seem lovely when it's open and in full effect.
author: Djerica L.

description: Best place for a photo op, as you can see on Instagram. Not only because these are the Full House houses, but also because it's just so damn picturesque. It's nice to just sit in Alamo Square and watch the sunset with the Painted Ladies. And yes, it's insanely crowded, so go up high to take the photo or get up early/come late!
author: Judy S.

description:
THE PARK ACROSS THE PAINTED LADIES IS CLOSED.
We wanted to have a picnic at the park and saw that the entire park is gated off.  Theyre doing renovations to the restrooms or something. I'd go to look if youve never seen them but I think its pretty standard for an sf trip, but we were pretty disappointed. Im not sure how long they are closed for though.
author: Hana L.

description:
Yes, yes, ladidaaa, I know...*cue Full House theme music*

We've all heard that before.

The Painted Ladies are a typical and touristy SF fixture located in the heart of Alamo Square. If you can find street parking (generally free around here), you'll be lucky to walk to the square of grass and get a closer look at the beautiful and brightly colored ladies.

Nothing as breath-taking as the 16th Tile Steps or Land's Ends, but still a traditional part of the "when my out of town friends come, I need to take them here" list of things to do in SF.
author: Jodi H.

description:
I grew up watching Full House, so it was fun to see these houses from the opening. Another great thing is that the actual house on Broderick is just a few blocks away (I suggest driving it), so they can be visited at the same time. 
It's worth seeing, especially if you grew up watching the show. If not, it still has a beautiful park to view the city from right across the street. We watched the sun set over the city & painted ladies in the park I've evening, it was gorgeous. Definitely worth doing!
author: Denae L.

description:
10AM on Sunday, February 1, 2015 - finally got to see The Painted Ladies!

After living in the Bay Area for a few years growing up, I never did make it here.

So in 2015 when I found myself in the city, I made it a point to see the iconic houses from the Full House lead in, and that adorn the front of many postcards.

No construction going on - just absolutely beauty. 

Though I will say - wow - I'm glad I don't have people standing outside my house all day taking pictures :) Or crowding Alamo Square, right across the street.


Nevertheless, beautiful neighborhood. Absolutely beautiful day when I went, so was very, very pleased. 

Definitely a sight to see!
author: Kristin Leigh M.

description:
These are the houses in the Full House credits.  But not the House where the Tanner family lived. That's a bit away. 
They are in good shape but not as pretty as in the credits
author: David C.

description: Very cool to see if you are into architecture. Although the entire attraction is only a street long, it is beautiful to view, as it is right across from a park on a hill! The poor people in the house must always have people posing outside their homes! You don't have to get off if you drive by, you could just take a look as you are passing.
author: Amelia J.

description:
There is construction going on in Alamo Square and the grass across the street from The Painted Ladies is no longer there as a result. However, it is still worth the trip to admire the gorgeous architecture & take pictures! If you are in the area, or visiting SF...take time out to visit this landmark! It won't take long, and will be well worth the wait.

Heads up: if you are looking for the Full House house featured during the opening credits, this is not the place! The address is: 1709 Broderick, SF 94115.
author: Sanaz A.

description:
*Cue full house theme song*

Nice attraction to behold, but we didn't spend more than a few minutes looking. The houses are beautiful, and I'd never be able to afford to live there, so it's nice to imagine what it would be like to live there!

PRO TIP- the park across from the painted ladies is known to have some homeless that are becoming notorious for stealing cameras/phones as you try to take a pic of these ladies. Keep a watchful eye before taking out and using your camera!
author: Suzanne B.

description: Not only was it beautiful to see the the painted ladies but the view behind it while relaxing in the park was so refreshing. And the day was nice and sunny, when in San Francisco books are always a must.
author: Tamara C.

description:
Beautiful houses, and pretty expensive pieces of real estate as well! 

The view is great from Alamo Park - I came here after a long day of SF touring, and was glad to have ended it here on a peaceful note. If you're a Full House fan, you'll recognize these houses from the opening credits. It's a very hilly area, so expect to get a calf workout while you're here. Great place for photos, and really encompasses a lot of what SF is about (classic SF-style houses in the front, skyline way in the back!)

I wonder how the actual residents of these houses feel knowing that their house is constantly being photographed...well, fame does come with consequences!
author: Tashnuva E.

description: Cute local buildings in beautiful colors. A lot tourists around the place. Hope it's not disturbing for residents.
author: Maruko X.

description:
"Everywhere you look..Everywhere you go...There's a heart...A hand to hold onto. 
Everywhere you look..Everywhere you go ..There's a place Of Somebody who needs you" 
If you recognize those lyrics you know what this is. 

Kind of anti-climatic but still pretty cool to see if you've never been in SF before. It's part of the opening scene of Full House so definitely an iconic spot. Not sure if anyone really lives in the houses but I wouldn't want to since there's always a bunch of people taking pictures outside. There's a mini park outside where you can sit and enjoy the view. 

Must see for SF Tourists!
author: Jessie H.

description:
I was so happy to finally make it to see the Painted Ladies in Mid June during a short trip to SF before heading home to NYC. The cottages are so beautiful and such artistic detail. And was SO EASY to get to, I hopped on the bus from downtown and there in 20 minutes. Lots of tourists were there. Oh yeah, I waited SO many years to get there, and my camera battery went kaput.  I got one video in. Noooooooo!! So my cell Camera did all the work. Thank God!!
 What more can I say!! They are just simply beautiful. The only disappointment is that the Alamo Square park is undergoing renovations and access is closed until Fall 2016. I will be back to visit.
author: Linda B.

description: I am always in SF checking out new places. First time here and This is pretty neat to see. BIG FULL House fan growing up. Not only that you could see the whole city from up here at the park. Definitely a picture moment! Make sure to bring a camera or a phone full of memories! The houses are are nicely painted and very well maintained. I can't tell which one was used for the full house show tho. It's cool how they placed the 50 Super Bowl sign here.
author: Cindy W.

description: Totally worth the long bus ride and walk. Firstly, the houses were beautiful and super photo friendly. Secondly, it's from Full House so how could you not come here
author: Jade L.

description:
3 stars because full house is overrated 

Would give the houses a 5 star rating if not for their connection to full house
author: Brad F.

description:
When I see the painted ladies, of course I think of the opening of one of my favorite TV shows as a kid, "Full House". 

I had to come here because I loved the show so much and wanted to see the beautiful ladies in person! The architecture is amazing and the buildings are very well kept. These beauties are only a few miles away from the Full House house on 1709 Broderick Street so it's easy to see them both in one short trip!

There are areas on the grass to enjoy the view, and I saw many people having a picnic, walking their dogs, or enjoying a book. Excellent view, but it can get very crowded!
author: Stacy W.

description:
Everywhere you look there's a heart, a hand to hold to!

Like everyone else who reviewed this place, this brought back memories - especially childhood memories because Full House was a great show!

I was really looking forward to go and visit this historic landmark which gained popularity from the opening credits of the show. Unfortunately, it was disappointing. I was expecting this place to have an open field with a grassy park. The grass was dry and it looked dead. One of the houses was being remodeled and it was an eye sore (refer to my picture).

Parking was also hard to find around this area. I circled around a couple times to find parking. Make sure to park appropriately since it was hilly.

Anyway, this was still a great landmark to take out-of-towners to.
author: Aj C.

description: Definitely a must-see! The view of the skyline over the houses is fantastic!
author: Laura D.

description: The painted ladies always offer a nice backdrop for pictures! They're just nice to look at. At the time there is construction going on at the park across the street from where you get the best pictures. They've however left a space for people to still have access. Doesn't take much time to park and snap a few pics.
author: Eddie C.

description:
One of the tourist attractions most likely to see in SF. 
The park is being remodeled under construction so that higher view is not there .. the grass isn't as green, when you see Bob Sagat in the intro to Full House!
author: J V.

description:
Full House was my jam when I was a kid. Rewatching episodes on Netflix you realize just how ridiculous some of the scenarios were - but alas, nostalgia trumps reality. 

If you are a 90's kid like me you will really appreciate seeing these ladies in person. Featured predominantly in the credits of Full House - some confuse it with the house where the Tanners lived - however these aren't the houses used for the shots of the tanner home - although that house is just a few blocks away! These are featured when they zoom out from the family picnic in the park.

Speaking of said park (Alamo Square) - that's where you can get a great view and photos! It's right across the street and I found parking fairly easy.

The houses are old Victorian style homes - all lined up in a nice row and feature light pastel colors that really give them an overall unique look. The best part is you see these classic homes - and the modern buildings in the distance - it's a visually stunning contrast.
author: Blue A.

description: This is a go spot if your visiting SF, that is if your in the neighborhood. A park across the street will give you a nice view and pictures. I do wonder how the residents of these homes feel about people standing and looking through windows and constantly taking pictures and holding up traffic....wonder how I would feel....
author: N And N K.

description: PLEASE do NOT go up onto people's porches and stand at their front door to take photos. Believe it or not.. People live there. I was across the street watching at least 10 people walk up the steps and to the front door of somebody's home. It's seriously not okay, and I feel so bad for whoever lives there. Take photos from across the street, maybe some close ups if you want. But don't walk up to somebody's front door to take photos.
author: Shelley K.

description: Painted ladies is by Alamo park which is just one of the scenes from the full house show. When they are in the picnic as a family and the house are in the background. It's not the actual full house home that's in another street. I think that's the confuses people. But u can search it on here and your able to get to the actual house. Kids loved the park.
author: Miguel N.

description:
I feel for the owners of the painted ladies what with all the tourists but these houses are iconic and lovely. Look at the painted ladies from Alamo Square and youll also see a great view of downtown.

And yes in full house there is the opening scene where they picnic at Alamo Square so yay for reliving 90s TV shows with Bob Saget, Mary Kate & Ashley.

4 stars only because I'm not huge fan of tourist spots and my friend and I had to doge a few tourists with their selfie sticks.
author: Mimi T.

description: Went to see the Painted Ladies from Full House today! Great spot, right across from a park! I feel like Danny Tanner!
author: Rhett B.

description:
Beautiful sight to see, especially with the SF backdrop behind them. Worth a visit, for sure!

Head to the top of the park across the street for the best shot!
author: Melanie G.

description: Let's be real... they're just houses lol and there are so many home in San Fran that look exactly like this. But we were able to get parking easily so it was worth it. It was a nice to stop and check out the famous spot but if you don't have time or aren't in the area you won't be missing much.
author: Alyssa L.

description:
Although this is a San Francisco landmark, this is a waste of time to just visit to see the houses. Yes, they are beautiful, the view behind them is great, and the history (Full House) is there, this should not take longer than 10 minutes if you are just there for a viewing.

This is not the actual Full House, house, but it is the houses that are shown in the opening credits. This however is a great place to visit if you are just visiting touristy areas, like I was. I was just in this spot for no more than 10 minutes for pictures and moved on to the next tourist spot.
author: Melvin M.
