description: Beautiful homes! Our cute Lyft driver warned us that they repainted them, so he on the lookout for that. We went on a gorgeous sunny day and took photos in front of it and across the street on the hill/playground area. Such a beautiful park, too!
author: Tony A.

description:
Picturesque view of the houses you see on San Francisco postcards, movies and tv shows (hey Full House of Fuller House, whichever one you prefer). You take pictures, you awe in their greatness seeing it for the first time in person, sit there and stare. It's a row of Victorian style houses that many people came to see whenever you're in San Francisco. It's best viewed right across the Alamo Square Park, where there's plenty of parking spaces. 

It's one to see if you're ever in the city and you wanted to see in person the ones you only see in pictures growing up. Enjoy!
author: Joy P.

description: So beautiful.. I could stay here all day. The little park across the street from the homes is a great spot to just sit on the grass and take in all of the beauty you're surrounded by. I love this city.
author: Miranda B.

description:
It's a little weird to be writing a review on a row of houses because, I mean, how the he** are you even supposed to rate a row of houses? Honestly just think about it for a second, it's not like it's a restaurant...or a business or even something that was built for hundreds upon thousands of people to enjoy as a collective monument. So how do you rate this out of 5? 

It's tough because these houses have become famous world wide for being on one of the most  iconic TV sitcoms ever made so it's a little hard not to have high hopes for when you come check them out. I am going with 4 stars because I expected to be taken back to the days of my childhood, coming home from school to seeing what lessons Danny Tanner would teach Djay, Stephanie and Michelle, What Uncle Jessie's hair looked like and what kind of Trouble uncle Joey would get into but I wasn't...it was more of a "oh..that's it?" but all in all it was still cool to be able to say I saw them.

 These houses weren't even used for filming, only in the opening credits and the actual house they depict living in isn't any one of these..it's about 20 minutes away..bummer.It seems like a lot of people expect the home owners to make sure the keep-up of them is just as they were during the 90's but seriously...why? It's not like the owners are responsible to keep the masses happy. Also some people think "poor owners, having to deal with tourists all day everyday" but c'mon...they knew and and still know what they got themselves into haha. 


So...when you're lost out there and you're all alone..or with friends...or a significant other...or, well I think you get the point. Check it out, just to say you did ;)
author: Kenny O.

description: I just visited in early May 2017 and the park across the street was doing some construction.   So, picture taking was very limited.  Other than than that, great place for pictures.
author: Daniel K.

description: Pretty neat to see the exact location of where Full House opening shot was taken. I grew up watching Full House and felt very nostalgic coming here. Clearly I wasn't the only one as I saw many other people coming here just to take a picture as well as ensure they found the right spot as they were all taking out their smart phones to find the Youtube video that shows the spot! If you are running out of things to do, this could be an option. Parking can be pretty scarce as it's all street parking.
author: TianChee S.

description:
Well, that's a bit of a let down. Yes these are historical homes and seeing them brings back a certain nostalgia of watching the intro to Full House. But the expectation and reality, as we all know too well are often not met.

The bus ride to even get here had us waiting for a good 20minutes that also involved a transfer, but that's on us so that is not a detraction.

What did detract from the experience was that the park that I've seen and thought it to be open was closed and under construction. What was possible for us to walk on are a small field of area with dirt areas as opposed to greenery that I've seen from photos. And construction signs that I think said "construction of painted ladies viewing area."

I'm glad I was able to see these Victorian era houses on my visit, its something checked off my list. But just make it a quick visit.
author: Jason Z.

description:
You can't go to San Francisco without gawking at these gorgeous ladies!  It's all cat calls and wolf whistles.  These Victorian beauties can make all passerby stand around with their mouths agape!

Like many, I was first familiarized with The Painted Ladies due to the opening credits of Full House.  Oh how I could have a picnic with Uncle Jesse on the lush green grass...  Anyways, the architecture is gorgeous.  It's classic Victorian/Edwardian and the details in these finely crafted masterpieces just pop.  While there isn't much to do besides take some pictures, sit around and enjoy the gorgeous San Francisco weather, or have a picnic with the Tanner family, it's definitely a touristy spot you should see at least once in your lifetime if you're in town.

Come by Postcard Row and see these ladies for yourself!  You can look but you can't touch.  They're classy ladies after all!
author: Joyce W.

description: Around midday I walked to see the painted ladies after walking the Panhandle and looking at the houses along Fell St and surrounding area. I had seen quite spectacular photos of these houses and I suspect these were taken late afternoon and probably with pretty good cameras. So when I crossed Alamo Square and got my first glimpse, well, to say I was disappointed was an understatement. However, I spent some time looking and photographing and convinced myself it was worth the walk. There were houses near Fulton that were pretty good too
author: Sue L.

description: These Victorian Homes are only worth taking a peek at if you're hanging out in the beautiful Alamo Square.  The best view will be at the top of Alamo Square facing Steiner St between Fulton and Hayes Streets.  Another one of my infamous, take a picture and move on sites.
author: Anthony G.

description:
Awe the Painted ladies, while I saw so many great houses in several neighborhoods while on vacation in this city, this was a must see for many reasons. The Full House picnic scene in the opening is filmed here and shows of these old victorian style homes. It is a tourist attraction but the park is beautful as well. 

So many great post cards showcase these ladies, and it is another iconic view in the city. It is a must see when you visit the city. 
We parked on the other side of the park and had to walk up a fairly steep hill to get to the top and to the ladies, but the walk was nice enough and worth the walk.
author: Tina S.

description:
Wasn't hard to find. 
Parking on the other hand was a different story.
We got lucky & found parking easily but for a Saturday afternoon, the park was crackin' & there wasn't much of any cars leaving & lots of cars coming.

Don't know how other people can give this less than 5 stars, it's an iconic staple in SF, whatevs.

Other than that, nothing much to really say :)

A check off of my bucket list!
author: Camille C.

description: A must see when touring SF. This can easily be a quick stop, taking no more than 5 minutes. Located across Alameda Park. Just as anywhere in SF, parking is a bit difficult.
author: Elaine D.

description: We wanted to go to this place and have a picnic in the park but the park was under construction. There was a short dirt hill to get a pic of the houses. They are beautiful. But it wasn't that exciting. Parking was easy. The houses surrounding are beautiful too. Be sure to stop by other landmarks too so your day doesn't feel wasted.
author: Krista P.

description: Touristy destination?  You betcha, but it was on our must see list while we were in SF, especially now we have the L.O. The first time I visited a long ass time ago, it was hard to find.  Now with Waze and the internet, it was a cinch.  I asked my parents why they never brought us here to take pictures an they said they never knew about it.  They still didn't understand the fuss, but proceed to snap pictures anyway. I have been enamored ever since I saw these magnificent buildings in the opening credit of Full House.  I love the look of Victorian homes and thankful that so many survived in San Francisco.  I wished LA wasn't so quick to tear down their Victorian homes in favor of ugly, no character apartment buildings.
author: Rochelle R.

description: Definitely a spot you have to visit if you're in town. Head across the street to Alamo Square and to the top of the hill for an awesome view of both the Painted Ladies and the city -- gorgeous!
author: Justine J.

description:
We always hear about all the faaaaabulousss men that live here in San Francisco, but did you know that in this amazing city also dwells some faaaabulousss ladies?

Adorned with brightly lit colors that allure even travelers from afar and with shapely curves that one can't help but notice. Classy, elegant, and captivating; these ladies know just how to grab your attention and have you admire their wondrous beauty. 

Enchanted by their mere presence, your senses are submerged deep within her intricate details causing even the most strongest of strong to fall prey. These head turning ladies are here to perform and put on a great show.

The Painted Ladies have been here since 1892 and were built through 1896 and have since survived the 1906 major earthquake. Architecturally classic with its Victorian and Edwardian style, these homes are often referred to as Painted Ladies, and remain one of San Francisco's main attractions.

Nestled in Alamo Square, you can enjoy beautiful views of these rare and unique homes. Along the backside, you also get an astounding backdrop view of the Financial District and of downtown SF. Classified as Postcard Row, there is lovely juxtaposition between modern and classic, old and new. 

This is a very famous site and featured on many popular tv shows such as Full House. Among its iconic SF counterparts, The Painted Ladies can stand on their own and is admired by many. 

Perfect for picture taking, strolling throughout, or enjoying a simple picnic; this is the absolute destination for anyone who enjoys great scenery and would love to capture a bit of San Francisco whimsy. 

Eat your heart out boys!
author: Ann S.

description: These homes are iconic, a landmark that has been tied to San Francisco living for as long as I can remember. Some of you may recognize it because you are "Full House"/"Fuller House" fans and many just recognize it from a postcard, a magnet or a photo you may have seen of San Francisco. Anyway, they have been around forever. Even though I am from the Bay Area, I had not seen them, when I lived out there, but took me a move to Hawaii and Louisiana to finally make my way out there. They're up on a slanted hill, perfect for photo ops, when the houses are not under construction with scaffolding in front of them. If you are visiting San Francisco for the first time, you'll want to come here to snap a pic, since they are one of the more popular sites to visit in this city (up there with the Golden Gate Bridge, Lombard's crooked street, Coit Tower, Fisherman's Wharf, etc). When it's not under construction, visit the park across the street, too. I love coming back here because the homes are so beautiful and such a historic part of San Francisco that I have had more interest in during my adult life. Bookmark on your Yelp App!
author: Rebecca W.

description:
These San Francisco landmarks are Victorian masterpieces! 
Set between Alamo Square and downtown San Francisco in the murky fog behind it, this is a beautiful place to behold. The Victorian theme runs throughout each of the buildings that make up the Painted Ladies. Each are private residences. Danny Tanner lives somewhere around here. Just ask DJ. 
It's a beautiful scene with the skyscrapers of downtown SF peaking out from behind the Ladies. It's a great part of town to get lost in, with lots of good hills. 
I recommend getting your selfies in on the hill that overlooks the Painted Ladies in Alamo Square.
author: Curt C.

description:
Ann S.'s review is better than what is about to follow...  Glad I let the FTR get away.

My first thought every time I see The Painted Ladies is:  I wonder what it's like to live in a house that is a historic landmark and one of the biggest tourist stops in SF...?  Do you think to yourself that someone is watching you?  Are you in the bathroom realizing that a tourist from half-way across the globe is taking a picture of your home?  Do people ring your doorbell and ask if Uncle Jesse is home?  Is the guy who played Uncle Joey out front trying to cash in on his decades-ago fame?  It makes the mind swim with possible scenarios.

On the list of "Things You Have to See When You Visit SF", The Painted Ladies are pretty high up.  Why it is entirely worth the trip is not because of the houses themselves.  In fact, there are a lot of much cooler houses spread through-out the Western Addition and The Haight.  It is the vista you get while looking at the houses.  Driving by at street-level, you might kinda shrug your shoulders.  Standing across the street and up the hill on Alamo Square, different ball-game.  The houses are framed perfectly by a backdrop of downtown.  The juxtaposition of the old Victorian houses with the 21st Century City in the background is, in itself, a nice reminder of the history and dynamism we are at once surrounded by.  And on a nice day, it's simply a beautiful spot.  Hanging on the hill on the East-side of Alamo Square and looking down over SF is a great way to spend a few hours on the weekend. 

I'm still on the look-out for Danny Tanner.  OK...  Actually, I'm on the look-out for DJ.
author: Adam S.

description:
I've been to San Francisco many times, but had never made my way to this iconic row of houses. Finally, I did it the last time I was in town. They're lovely and charming, and the neighborhood is fun to chill in for a bit, too, so it's not like you're going out of your way just to look at some houses -- there are things to do nearby, too! 

If you're touring SF, then definitely carve a bit of time out to head this way. Bring a picnic and plop yourself across the street from this well-known view in the neighboring park, and stay a while. Take it all in -- from here, you can see great views of most of the city, if it's a clear and sunny day.
author: Hilary H.

description: Beautiful homes. Brings me back to my childhood watching the Tanners grow up. Love it.
author: James O.

description: I love the park across the street. It's a great place to relax or even have a picnic. We came during the late evening so it wasn't as "magical". But it is definitely a place to visit when you are in San Francisco, especially because their is a snapchat filter for it (the houses). I would come here for a nice stroll if I lived in the city.
author: Cherise N.

description:
When many people thing San Francisco, they think of the Painted Ladies! For many, it conjures memories of the opening credits of Full House, but the Painted Ladies have also been featured in many TV shows and movies!

The Painted Ladies are inhabited homes, so a visit to this landmark is relatively quick. For my party, it was definitely worth it to make a quick visit as the architecture and overall beauty of the homes deserves to be admired! 

There is park across the street, which is the best spot to view the Painted Ladies and get some pictures.
author: Steph H.

description: The Painted Ladies are famous houses that many mistake to be the Tanner house from the popular TV show Full House. In fact, none of these houses are the Tanner house and you are about a mile away from the real house in the show. Nonetheless, these houses are pretty cool looking and are a staple of the real estate in the city. The park across the street is nice too and that is actually where they filmed the picnic scene from the TV show.
author: Vats A.

description: The painted ladies are pretty for a quick photo. The Alamo Park was closed when we were there for resodding.... BE AWARE of car thefts! Remove all things from car even  you are only there for a few minutes!
author: Kimberly G.

description:
This is such a great historical site to look at while you're in San Fran. My family and I had the opportunity to visit this location while we were in town. If you are in town this place is a great place to go to and just marvel at the artistic values of the painted ladies. Two were currently under construction while we came to visit and yes if you are wondering. Actual people live in those houses still. This is NOT the actual full house but its just the location where the gang ate at at the end of the opening credits.

Just a little fun fact. The house on the left corner was just sold last month for $3.2 million.
author: Jethro M.

description:
-- 7/100 reviews for 2016 --
What can I say? Lovely park with a great view of the painted ladies. Beautiful houses that has been photographed abundant of times. Wished I could have enjoyed a nice picnic or lunch at the park but we were in SF during a super windy and rainy weekend. Would definitely love to come back.
author: Vanessa L.

description: When I was coming to the bay area, this was on top of my list of must see places in San Francisco, since I didn't have enough time to see it last time I was in SF several years ago. One of the houses was under construction when I came there this past Labor day weekend. The park was packed, with people standing in front trying to take pictures.
author: Kim L.

description:
Everywhere you look. Everywhere you go. There's a heart. A hand to hold onto. 
Yep - that's the Full House intro song, and these lovely ladies are the homes in the background of the show. It can be crowded on the weekend, but is a beautiful park. Pack a picnic lunch and sit on the hill across from the Ladies.
author: Kim K.

description: I had to come to this spot because I wanted to feel like the tanners when they had a picnic in the park right across from these victorian homes.  These houses are very beautiful and you can see that many tourist come to capture some snap shots.  If you are in San Francisco you should definitely come by to check them out.  The best shot can be taken from the park right across the street.
author: Linda E.

description:
Sad for us that the middle Lady was under construction, so while we're glad we veered this way on our way to dinner, I'd have been upset to make a special trip this way. 

Still, an iconic part of the city and a cute little detour on our walk through this side of the city.
author: Nicole H.

description:
Come here and while walking around make sure you play the full house theme song the whole time. It will bring back good memories.

There's always a free parking spot and the park is cool spot to hang out and relax before heading out into the normal SF tourists traps which cost you an arm and a leg.
author: Realtor Karl B.

description:
Beautiful and Colourful Victorian Houses But Not The Most Impressive in SF

My mother and I visited The Painted Ladies during the afternoon of August 1st. We took the MUNI bus from our Airbnb apartment in the Mission District to Alamo Square, where these beautiful houses are located. 

The Painted Ladies are a well-known row of beautiful and colourful Victorian houses with detailed architecture that were featured in the opening credits of the TV show, Full House. 

The bus dropped us off a couple of blocks away from Alamo Square/The Painted Ladies and it was a short walk to get there. We climbed to the top of the hill in the park (Alamo Square) and admired the fantastic views of these beautiful houses with the San Francisco downtown skyline and high-rise buildings in the background, while taking photos. There were quite a few other people there, taking photos as well. 

After checking out The Painted Ladies, we walked across the park (Alamo Square) to the other side, where we discovered a few Victorian houses that were much more impressive and colourful than The Painted Ladies, so I recommend checking those out. The park itself was beautiful and was perched on top of a hill with gorgeous views that overlooked the city. If I had had more time, it would have been a nice place to spend an afternoon relaxing or having a picnic. 

We didn't spend too much time in this area and after wandering around the surrounding neighbourhood to check out more unique houses, we caught a bus to our next destination (Haight-Ashbury). 

Although I enjoyed visiting The Painted Ladies, they were not the most beautiful or most impressive Victorian houses that I discovered during my trip. I walked around a few residential neighbourhoods and found many more unique, historic and gorgeous picturesque homes throughout them (The Castro, Mission District and Haight-Ashbury areas in particular). 

If you are interested in admiring the beautiful colours and intricate architecture of these classic Victorian houses, I recommend exploring off the beaten path and visiting the neighbourhoods, in addition to The Painted Ladies.
author: Brittany T.

description: Beautiful homes , the park across is closed  would have loved to get a shot from higher ground
author: goldiebx c.

description: Difficult to find parking but once you do, the Alamo Park across from the Painted Ladies is nice for a stroll (you get some good views of the city from different corners of the park) and for a little picnic. Sadly 2 of the 6 Painted Ladies had scaffolding and we're having work done on the day we went, but a sweet, nostalgic view anyway!
author: Shweta K.

description: I USE TO LOVE FULL HOUSE SO HOW COULD I NOT LOVE IT HERE! We went here last night and it was so cool, there was all these people recording for a movie & it was all light up & it was just awesome to see the Painted Ladies at night and I can't wait to go back to see them today in daylight!
author: Alexandria D.

description:
let me start out saying this is a place not to be missed while in SF. This place is iconic and yes its so worth every hard step getting here for the view. i would go out of my way to come here and just sit on the park and enjoy the view and just gag on the scenery on every breath. anyways its amazing and a must see while in SF. 

i really haven't been to this place before til my friend took me here since he was a lyft driver and was giving me a tour of SF in his car with a few brief moments of getting off and snapping a few pictures. finally after so many years of coming to SF, i told myself how have i not been here, because it must be a tourist spot or stuff i never imagine myself coming here. then i told myself i have to come back and take some photos with my DSLR camera in the future. also during the tour i found that there are some awesome foodie spots nearby and a cool ice cream parlor which a lot of people line up for which is maybe 0.01 miles from the park. i haven't tried yet cuz the line was out the door but one of these days when i feel fatty i will have to stop by. ice scream you scream haha ice cream say what??! yea ice cream!!!! lol 

a few weeks ago during april 2015 i had made a trip specifically for these houses.  i had came here with a group of my photography buddies to photograph some amazing pictures. The group and i waited in the park til it was the time where the natural lighting shines on each one of the houses. once we got the winner shot, mission was complete. 

the parking here can be hard time find and is very limited since its all street parking only. i mean parking can be a hassle on busy days or weekends since this is an iconic tourist spot where people like coming here to snap a picture for SF memories. 

lets see during my relaxing time on the grass, it was very sunny and hot and i was in my shorts and a hat. i felt very relax while i sat their for over an hour waiting for the natural light to shine on each one of the houses. i saw tourists coming here with their tri pod and getting in our way for the photos. haha i just wanted to go over and ask them to move or just pick them up and move them over haha. i also see locals coming here in their bathing suit or shirtless tanning or trying toe ben their tans. i also see some locals bringing their cute dogs to come here and play frisbee with them. so i imagine this park is dog friendly as well. i also seen this guy doing his math homework right in front of the houses, we were amazed how he knew how to choose his spot to do his homework. just a very great place to chill or relax and read a book or even people watch. 

1. come here to people watch 
2. come here to play with your pets or dog
3. come here to relax your mind 
4. come here to snapchat, fb, ig, twitter, or vine
5. come here to take pictures for memories 
6. come here to tan or even your tan lines
7. come here picnic and eat your sandwich or salads
8. come here to meet your friend or love or buddy or whatever maybe even a date 
9. come here to take a walk after your meal 
10. come here just to be cool and explore 

hopefully i have pursade you to come check out the scene and the view as well. i bet you won't be disappointed. also vote for my review and have a nice day and thanks for reading. follow me or add me if you haven't because i love to meet new people.
author: Alex T.

description: It's such a nostalgic feeling to see the Painted Ladies in person. I just kept playing the Full House theme song in my head. My friend and I decided to be cute and to have a picnic in front of the Painted Ladies like in full house. The houses are well maintained and you can see them from the park across the street. If you're interested in hearing about the history of the houses, several tours come through this area and you can join one or just eves drop. We took muni to the park but I can see how street parking could be a problem. The grass closer to the Painted Ladies is sadly dead so it's not the most comfortable thing to sit on. Nevertheless, the Painted Ladies are an icon of the Bay and a must see.
author: Mindy Y.

description: The Painted Ladies are an institution in San Francisco. Its a row of colorfully painted, classic San Francisco architecture. You can admire them from the hillside or get up and close. They aren't quite as bright in person as Instagram filters will lead you to believe, but that muted look really works in foggy SF. I recommend taking a picnic in the park to really soak them up, but you can also do a drive by photo!
author: Kari G.

description: One of SF's landmark to visit. So glad I get to visit this place. Make sure you bring a light jacket when you visit in the summer time as it is pretty chilly in SF. The Victorian houses are beautifully well maintained except the landscape across the street. There is parking on all side of the streets but you have to have the perfect timing as it gets pretty crowded. Lots of tourist visiting and taking selfies. You can also take a stroll if you visit the area nearby. Great view of the city if you go a little further up. You'll be reminded of the show Full House when you visit as they use this backdrop on the shows opening. I recommend this place. It'll be worth your visit.
author: Arlene S.

description: Beautiful. Iew of the old victorian homes. If your a 90s kid then must see for the full house effect.
author: Michael A.

description: Fun to see if you're a Full House fan. Large lawn area for picnics. Great place for lounging on the weekend. It's fun to stop and take snap a photo if you're by but otherwise...not really worth making your way over just for it.
author: Karen L.

description: Yes because, it's a must see if you were a fan of full house! Super touristy but I definitely thought it was fun to snap some pictures while singing the theme song :)
author: Shaili K.

description: Only reason we came by these houses is they are in the opening credits of Full House! We got a great picture up at the park with the houses in the background. Wish the actual Full House House was here. We thought it was, but then realized it was at a different location. So we left to go find it, but still enjoyed this beautiful street of Victorian Houses!
author: Diana W.

description:
The Painted Ladies were the Houses from the show Full House.

It is a good photo op and great to say you been there type deal. Parking can be a nightmare and there are always people around to snap shots.

On a nice day, you can chill in the park and relax.
author: Roger A.

description: Fun place to stop, beautiful architecture . Fun little stop to make if you are in the area. The homes are beautiful and hold some fun 90s nostalgia if you were a Full House fan.
author: Idaho Travelers S.

description: They're much prettier in the online pictures than they are in person. I don't know why they can't keep the grass green, as it was really dry and brown why I was there this weekend, after coming from a super lush and green Dolores park. Anyways, still an ok attraction to see in 2 minutes as its the classic SF craftsman homes that we locals love.
author: Natasha K.

description: The place was just pretty houses with a view behind them, but there are many places like that in California and San Francisco. I think the reason it is so popular is because it is featured in the Full House tv show. There's a park under construction behind it and no public restroom, so the scenery across from it is not too pretty.
author: Margaret P.

description: very beautiful area, park and houses that brings people back to the 90's tv show full house. Tourist flock this area of SF to take tons of pictures, picnic in the park and just frolic around the area. Summer weather is great but sometimes it can get chilly so bring a jacket. Its on top of the hill so good luck walking up there and if you drive, 0 parking in the area.
author: Juan T.

description: This is a neat place to stop if you're in the area.  The painted ladies ate a unique architectural feature of San Fran;  But I would not work too hard to get here.  The viewing area across the street is also being renovated right now. Also, respect the families who live in these homes.  Would you want strangers on your porch?
author: Jennifer S.

description: These are cool--and it goes beyond their Full House legend--and somehow, it even extends beyond their Fuller House legend (growing by the day). In a vacuum, they are beautiful on their own. A fine example of the Victorian architecture that predominates the city's landscape. Must do if you're a tourist and not so bad idea if you live here and happen to be in the area.
author: Renard M.

description: Overrated. San Francisco is full of amazing architecture. It was hard to be wowed by these houses after walking down Haight Street and through Pacific Heights. The only thing that sets these houses apart is that they've been photographed so many times before. Unless you're already in the neighborhood, skip it and buy a postcard instead.
author: Kayleigh S.

description: Fun spot to visit, great historical background and beautiful architecture. The park was under construction so that was a bummer and there was a crowd of people so definitely not an under the radar spot, but still a cool spot to stop by if in the area
author: Nick H.

description: Make a visit to the Painted Ladies, it's a must do! It only takes a second to see these magnificent houses and take a picture and it's worth it.
author: Ashley S.

description:
The new viewing area is under construction, so it was hard to get the completed view of The Painted Ladies and the city behind it, so it'll just be a review of the houses. 

I've seen a lot of old houses in the Bay Area, many that look similar to The Painted Ladies. What I think makes these houses stand out more than anything is how it manages to gather so many people in a quite part of town. It's just as fun, if not more fun to watch the people watching the house. Where else are you going to see people try to pose like a model on the stairs of a random house? The randomness of the place, how its own reputation manages to bring people here is just impressive. There's no commercialization of these houses. You could literally buy them, but for the everyday person there's no caricature artists or silvery robots dancing nearby, which makes this landmark stand in sharp contrast with much of SF. 

I hear it's near some nice restaurants people like to talk about, so if you wanted to create a big contrast between your New American Sunday brunch experience, try going to the house where Full House is set in, the gap doesn't get any bigger.
author: Trevor N.

description: Fun fact: this is not the Full House house. It is however in the opening credits. The park is small but lovely and has a dog area on the west side where they're free to roam. There weren't too many people in the area so it was nice a relaxing. The park also has good views of the rest of the city.
author: Emily P.

description: An avid full house watcher--had to visit the Painted ladies as well as the house on Borderick street! Not too impressed. Paint jobs and upkeep has taken away from the originality. Plus the park across the street was in shambles when we visited! Good for a quick drive by photo but no reason to spend more than 10 minutes there. Visit the Mrs Doubtfire house in the area after this one and the church from sister act! Take the Hollywood tour of houses!
author: From C.

description:
Why there is only two reviews on these iconic homes is a mystery to me. Mind boggling really. Nonetheless, I am honored to post a third along with Adam and my wonderful Yelp friend Ann. 

Standing atop Alamo Sq hill you get an amazing view of these fabulous homes, indestructible homes, the famous Painted Ladies. I actually saw Danny Tanner grabbing the mail upon my visit and the weirdest thing, the Full House theme music was playing. I dont know where it was coming from, a giant speaker up in the sky seemed like. 

Anyone at the park a few days ago may have witnessed my Daughter and I taking turns doing the "jail pose" catching these wondrous houses and a gorgeous city in the back drop. They really are a must see. Although, to my dismay, two of the homes were being worked on and covered up. Was not too pumped about that, oh well.
author: Steve L.

description: A San-Fran must see. Full House nostalgia. I've been to San Francisco many times but never got to see the houses in person. The parking is almost close to impossible. We got lucky after driving around the park twice and getting a spot on a decline and had to parallel park. Yipes! No accidents. :P You're better off parking away and walking up but only if you can make it up all the hills!
author: Tasia C.

description: Who doesn't love seeing these iconic houses! San Francisco is one of my favorite cities and I really don't get tired of seeing the Painted Ladies! It really is a just see. And yes it reminds you also of the hit TV show full house. They are renovating one house at a time so just beware. You won't get a perfect picture of them!
author: Marie P.

description: Loved this view!!!! It was a rainy, cold, windy day but I definitely made time to see these famous beauties!!
author: Kassy T.

description: went during the time of day where the large buildings at the top of the street casted a perfect shadow over all 5 or 6 houses. lol. still got my pictures for social media, then uber'd to somewhere more exciting. the park across the street does have a great view of several parts of SF including the row of houses. so, besides shouting the intro to 'full house' at the top of my lungs and twirling around on the grass, i probably don't need to come back here again.
author: Marissa M.

description: Whomp whomp!!!!  Soo, the pretty ladies are cool to see.  The Alamo park is awesome as well (because part of Full House opening was taped there :)).  that being said, 2 of the "ladies" were all covered by scaffolding to get updated/repainted.  I understand, this is necessary, but basing my review off of our experience, I can't rate it high.  We didn't get to even see 2 of the houses and there was a ton of noises from neighboring construction going on.  If you are reading this and haven't planned your trip out to SF yet, I'd strongly recommend waiting another month or even two, before you depart.  Just an fyi...
author: Brian H.

description: Great open area to sit and talk with friends. The actual houses aren't as brightly colorful as expected, but it's a great place with a great view. There are nice benches facing the painted ladies.
author: Grace K.

description:
Painted Ladies? More like "Not painted Ladies"!

Okay, so maybe this review is not fully true however when my friend and I were in San Francisco, the Painted Ladies were being re-painted and surrounded by construction equipment. 

A shame for us but I'm sure they will look better than ever when they're finished.
author: Evan K.

description: The park is definitely a must see if your visiting San Francisco! The parking is free, but gets very crowded especially on weekends! It's close to restaurants! Or even have a Picnic in the park! It over looks part of the city right behind the houses! Will definitely bring friends and family to see this!
author: Gloria M.

description: It was a sunny day in November but it seemed much brighter on TV.  Anyhow, the area is under a lot of construction at the time.  I guess I would come back  but something definitely off my checklist especially if you grew up in the 90's #fullhouse ;-)
author: Anthony E.

description: I loved visiting SF. my sweet friend took me around to a lot of hot spots in town, including the painted ladies. First of all, this is NOT the full house house just FYI. :-/ it's a beautiful purple house nearby that full house was filmed in but this little park/patch of grass across from the painted ladies is definitely nostalgic if you were born in the 80's or grew up with Full House. It's the view you saw every time the show was starting. Aside from the fame of he spot, it's quite beautiful- the views and all. Love San Francisco!
author: Tanna D.

description:
Definitely worth a visit. I'm from Northern California, and I've lived in SF, however, I never took the time to go. Now I wonder what took me so long.

Parking was easy. The view was sweet. The dog park looked cool. There's even a semi-decent tennis court in the middle of the park.
author: Viet N.

description: The park across the street from the homes is the nicest view in my opinion. You see the Painted Ladies and the SF skyline. Great for a walk, picnic, or just sitting with a friend enjoying the sunset.
author: Alyssa L.

description: I wasn't very impressed with these houses. Unless you are a Full House fan, these can be skipped. The square next to has a ton of dead grass so it's not as pretty of a location anymore.
author: Jena D.

description: Amazing view either of the city behind the painted ladies or the sunset on the other side of Alamo square.
author: Robin H.

description: For anyone who grew up watching Full House you will want to go to see the Painted Ladies. The Full House house in itself is very unimpressive. It has been painted and landscaped to be unrecognizable to what you remember on the show, so instead go here and relive the opening credits. It's got a great view of the city and the ocean so the sight in of itself is worth it. Now for the hard part. You'll need to trek to the top of the park to get to see it in all its glory so be prepared to get a workout in. That can really be said for just about anything in SF though.
author: Joshua C.

description: The walk to Alamo Square is great. It's also fun to watch other people take pictures here.
author: Gavin M.

description: Must see if your a full house fan or if you just want a pretty view of the city. Bring a blanket and enjoy the view with good company!
author: Lauren M.

description: I have lived in the city for most of my life but I never really found a reason to come here. But after going out of state for college, I realize how much I don't know the cool places in the city. I took it upon myself to finally visit this place spring break, and it was very pleasant! I actually walked here from Church Station. It wasn't a bad walk at all! It is a fairly quiet neighborhood, and it was really nice out so it was a great day for a little walk (or my lame excuse for "exercise"). Anyways, do come and take a gander if you've never been here! I know it's just a couple of houses that you can easily find pictures of on postcards and Google images, but it is a lot cooler once you get there and see it with your own eyes!
author: Julianne Z.

description: Such a great view of the city and the houses are beautiful. Besides that, it's so fun to sit on the grassy noll of the park with friends on a warm day.
author: Lee A.

description: The painted ladies are under construction as of June 24, 2014. I can see the draw because of the scenic backdrop but there's nothing to see right but sediment fences and scaffolding. Don't waste your time until it's finished.
author: Gerald H.

description:
I just didn't get those Ladies

SF is an amazing city and full of amazing architecture. It has SO MANY Victorian houses, which has much more interesting architecture than Painted Ladies. Alamo park is also so average and seems under-maintained, just trees and grass, good for dogs. With so much to do and see in SF, I would not recommend to plan a separate trip for this "landmark".
The only charm of this place that you can see modern skyline on the foreground of Victorian houses. The buildings on another side of the park are much more interesting.
author: Yelena Z.

description: Say hello to San Francisco! Now this is one iconic view. You'll see it in movies and TV shows. A little bit exciting to see it in real life! On a warm day, people flock to this park, and you may struggle to find a patch of grass. My advice is persevere, it's worth it.
author: Amy M.

description: How are there only four reviews here?  These homes are in so many iconic pictures of San Francisco, how can you not visit them.  Sadly, two of the six painted ladies are being painted this summer, so it's not so picturesque at this time.  But still meet to see none the less.  Love the view of the city in the background...
author: Cassandra A.
